evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the hist_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative explanations do not sufficiently account for the observed coordination failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_t2_interim inspection phase dated 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against common defeaters, ensuring that it cannot be easily dismissed or misinterpreted during the hist_t2_interim inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for deficiencies in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA model during the hist_t2_interim inspection.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim is resistant to common defeaters based on available evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is documented and available in the hist_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the hist_t2_interim context for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features observed in pushback operations for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25, as recorded in hist_t2_interim.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, and wingman constitute the relevant crew for communication/coordination in this context
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew during the incident
If the lack of warnings was due to other factors unrelated to communication breakdown

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly documents communication and coordination issues: the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver stopped and requested the instructor to take over (H2), and the instructor had to reassure and advise the trainee during pushback (H3), indicating evident communication/coordination breakdown among crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit documentation of communication attempts or failures beyond the tug crew; limited detail on headset operator and wingman communication

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction on the aircraft during the event
Reports or data indicating failure in aircraft systems
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the pushback on 12-25; the incident involved tug operation and procedural issues only (H1-H9).

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown includes ineffective signaling and lack of warnings
The trainee's decision to stop and hand over control indicates coordination issues
defeaters: Direct evidence of explicit miscommunication or conflicting instructions among crew
Evidence showing effective communication and coordination preventing errors
Additional details on the headset operator and wingman roles and interactions

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication occurred but was insufficient or ineffective (H1, H8), and coordination issues are implied by the trainee stopping and handing over control (H2, H3). The tug instructor's comment on inadequate visual signals and lack of warnings (H8) supports the presence of communication/coordination breakdown aligning with key features of the incident.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_t2_interim inspection phase dated 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed a marking or environmental deficiency present and observable during the specified inspection phase.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or observation of any environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim inspection phase dated 12-25.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is documented and available in the hist_t2_interim dataset.

defeaters: If the hist_t2_interim dataset did not include these history records or if the procedural deviation was not documented in the dataset.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The history evidence (H1-H9) documents the procedural deviation during pushback of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25, including the sequence of events, personnel involved, and the incident outcome, indicating the deviation is recorded and available in the hist_t2_interim dataset.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None, the evidence directly documents the procedural deviation and its availability.

node.statement: The procedural deviation aligns with key features observed in pushback operations for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25, as recorded in hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: The described pushback procedures and roles represent typical key features for Boeing 737-8AS pushback operations
The incident described is representative of the 12-25 event for 9H-QAA in hist_t2_interim
defeaters: If evidence showed the deviation was due to an unusual or non-standard procedure not typical in Boeing 737-8AS pushbacks
If the procedural deviation was unique to this incident and not observed in other similar operations
If the TRP or pushback procedures were different than described in the evidence

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence describes the pushback operation details, including the tug driver roles, the TRP location, and the deviation where the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier (H4, H7). The procedural elements such as communication and stopping methods are consistent with known pushback operations (H1, H2, H3, H8, H9), supporting alignment with key features but not explicitly confirming all procedural norms.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit comparison of the deviation to a standard procedural baseline in the evidence
